protocol_name: Primer design protocol for qPCR primers when testing the natural variation in expression
protocol_name_html: Primer design protocol for qPCR primers when testing the natural variation in expression
description: How to design primers for qPCR when testing the expression in different Arabidopsis accessions. A simple protocol - suggestions welcome.
protocol_affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
manuscript_citation:
The protocol was used for primer design in 

"Natural variation in plasticity of roots in salt", Magdalena Julkowska, Iko Tamar Koevoets, Selena Mol, Huub CJ Hoefsloot, Richard Feron, MarkTester, Joost J.B. Keurentjes, Arthur Korte, Michel A Haring, Gert-Jan de Boer, Christa Testerink, The Plant Cell Nov 2017, tpc.00680.2016; DOI: 10.1105/tpc.16.00680

compare_forks.protocol_name: Primer design protocol for qPCR primers when testing the natural variation in expression
compare_forks.protocol_name_html: Primer design protocol for qPCR primers when testing the natural variation in expression
compare_forks.affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology

authors_list.name: Magdalena Julkowska
authors_list.affiliation: King Abdullah University of Science and Technology

status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data: Go to 1001 genome SALK Genome DB and enter the AtXgABCDE identifier @ Search http://signal.salk.edu/atg1001/3.0/gebrowser.php
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Go to 1001 genome SALK Genome DB and enter the AtXgABCDE identifier @ Search http://signal.salk.edu/atg1001/3.0/gebrowser.php

components.data: If you have multiple splice variants of your gene check @ TAIR which gene models were observed (Gene specific website under “protein data”) and use most commonly observed splice variant observed for your primer designing
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If you have multiple splice variants of your gene check @ TAIR which gene models were observed (Gene specific website under “protein data”) and use most commonly observed splice variant observed for your primer designing

components.data: At 1001 genome SALK Genome DB choose “Col-0.MPI” from the “tracks” menu and at “Display” menu change “View:” from “Graphic” to “Text”.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: At 1001 genome SALK Genome DB choose “Col-0.MPI” from the “tracks” menu and at “Display” menu change “View:” from “Graphic” to “Text”.

components.data: Make sure you have your 5’ UTR (the end of your gene) in the view window and that the correct splice variant is purple.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Make sure you have your 5’ UTR (the end of your gene) in the view window and that the correct splice variant is purple.

components.data: Copy the Col-0 sequence to word file
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Copy the Col-0 sequence to word file

components.data: Remove introns, indicated with lower case letters if you clicked on the gene
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Remove introns, indicated with lower case letters if you clicked on the gene

components.data: Make sure to write down the positions of nucleotides flanking the intron in your CDS
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make sure to write down the positions of nucleotides flanking the intron in your CDS

components.data: At “General Settings” in option “Load and Save – Please select special setting here:” choose qPCR and click on “Activate settings”.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: At “General Settings” in option “Load and Save – Please select special setting here:” choose qPCR and click on “Activate settings”.

components.data:
At General Settings -

“Primer Tm” = 58 / 60 / 58 ;

“max Tm diff.” = 2 ;

“Primer GC%” = 40 / 50 / 60 ;

 

At Advanced Settings -

“Max Poly-X” = 4 ;

“Max Self Complementarity” = 4;

“Max 3’ Self Complementarity” = 2;

“GC clamp” = 1,

“Product Size' = 70-100-150
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
At General Settings -

“Primer Tm” = 58 / 60 / 58 ;

“max Tm diff.” = 2 ;

“Primer GC%” = 40 / 50 / 60 ;

 

At Advanced Settings -

“Max Poly-X” = 4 ;

“Max Self Complementarity” = 4;

“Max 3’ Self Complementarity” = 2;

“GC clamp” = 1,

“Product Size' = 70-100-150

components.data: Paste your CDS sequence in “Main”, click “Pick Primers” (green button – cannot miss it) and pick the best primers (usually highlighted on top).
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Paste your CDS sequence in “Main”, click “Pick Primers” (green button – cannot miss it) and pick the best primers (usually highlighted on top).

components.data:
Preferentially pick primers of which the product is spanning the intron sequence (the location of which you wrote down at step 5), but that the primer sequences themselves are NOT overlapping the intron/exon boundary.

 

Preferentially chose primers that are closest to 5’ end of your CDS sequence, as they are going to be closest to polyA tail. If the primers are designed too far into 3’ end the chances are that you are not going to get any signal due to poor cDNA synthesis.

 

FYI – if you go back & forth in one window at Primer3PLUS and design multiple primers for multiple target genes the settings will be saved!
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Preferentially pick primers of which the product is spanning the intron sequence (the location of which you wrote down at step 5), but that the primer sequences themselves are NOT overlapping the intron/exon boundary.

 

Preferentially chose primers that are closest to 5’ end of your CDS sequence, as they are going to be closest to polyA tail. If the primers are designed too far into 3’ end the chances are that you are not going to get any signal due to poor cDNA synthesis.

 

FYI – if you go back & forth in one window at Primer3PLUS and design multiple primers for multiple target genes the settings will be saved!

components.data: If significant alignment is found with other than your target gene using BOTH primers then go back to step 8 and pick other primer pair
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If significant alignment is found with other than your target gene using BOTH primers then go back to step 8 and pick other primer pair

components.data: Check for primer specificity by BLASTING the primers against TAIR10 Transcripts (https://www.arabidopsis.org/Blast/ ).
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Check for primer specificity by BLASTING the primers against TAIR10 Transcripts (https://www.arabidopsis.org/Blast/ ).

components.data: The sequences of the accessions are constantly added.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The sequences of the accessions are constantly added.

components.data: Check for the polymorphisms in the annealing primer sites by going back to 1001 genomes SALK Genome DB and selecting the sequences of all the accessions that are used for expression experiment (+ sequenced).
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Check for the polymorphisms in the annealing primer sites by going back to 1001 genomes SALK Genome DB and selecting the sequences of all the accessions that are used for expression experiment (+ sequenced).

components.data: Check whether your primer is found in all selected accessions by clicking “cmd” + “F” and pasting your primer sequence in the “Search” window.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Check whether your primer is found in all selected accessions by clicking “cmd” + “F” and pasting your primer sequence in the “Search” window.

components.data:
As soon as you enter the sequence the search function will tell you the number of the occurrence of the sequence in the window you are currently in => make sure that the number is matching the number of selected accession sequenced.

 

Make sure to reverse-compliment the rev. primers before searching the sequence (http://www.bioinformatics.org/sms/rev_comp.html ).

 

If the primer annealing site is not found in all accessions selected go back to step 8 and select new primers.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
As soon as you enter the sequence the search function will tell you the number of the occurrence of the sequence in the window you are currently in => make sure that the number is matching the number of selected accession sequenced.

 

Make sure to reverse-compliment the rev. primers before searching the sequence (http://www.bioinformatics.org/sms/rev_comp.html ).

 

If the primer annealing site is not found in all accessions selected go back to step 8 and select new primers.
